Description: Rhodia Inc., an acid manufacturer, agreed to pay a $2 million penalty and spend approximately $50 million on air pollution controls at eight production plants in four states across the country to settle allegations that the company violated the Clean Air Act.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2007/April/07_enrd_294.html

Description: Rhodia Inc. pleaded guilty to two felony violations of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act at an elemental phosphorus manufacturing plant in Silver Bow County, Montana. Pursuant to a plea agreement, Rhodia was required to pay $18 million in criminal fines and restitution and to clean up the site.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2004/January/04_enrd_029.htm

Description: Solvay S.A., a Belgian company, and Akzo Nobel Chemicals International B.V., a Dutch company, agreed to plead guilty and to pay a total of more than $72 million in criminal fines for their participation in international price-fixing cartels in the chemicals industry.

Description: Rhodia Inc. agreed to pay $2 million to Indiana, Louisiana and the federal government to resolve Clean Air Act violations. Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2007/April/07_enrd_294.html

Description: Solvay Specialty Polymers and Arkema Inc. agreed to pay a toal of $1.84 million to resolve a class action alleging that a plant in Gloucester County, New Jersey caused perfluorinated compounds (PFCs) to enter into the Paulsboro municipal water supply system. The settlement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally between them.
Private Litigation Case Title: Thomas et al v. Solvay Specialty Polymers USA, LLC et al
Info Source: https://www.nj.com/gloucester-county/2016/04/nj_plastics_company_settles_contaminated_water_law.html
